tit.e: Mochimaki (an event of scattering rice cakes)
tit.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 餅まき（もちまき）とは、上棟式などの神事に際して集まった人々へ餅をまく行事。
sen.e: "Mochimaki" is an event of scattering rice cakes for the people who come to a Shinto ritual, such as "jotoshiki" (the framework raising ceremony held during construction of a new building).
"Mochimaki" is an event of scattering rice cakes for people who come to a Shinto ritual, such as "jotoshiki" (the framework raising ceremony held during construction of a new building).
Mochimaki is an event of scattering rice cakes for people who come to a Shinto ritual, such as jotoshiki (the framework raising ceremony held during construction of a new building).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 由来は、上棟式（建前）などで災いを払うために行われた神事である散餅の儀（もしくは散餅銭の儀）が発展的に広まったものである。
sen.e: It originated from "sanpei no gi" (the ceremony of scattering rice cakes), or "sanpeisen no gi" (the ceremony of scattering rice cakes or coins), which was a Shinto ritual held during jotoshiki (also called "tatemae") and other ceremonies for praying there would be no problem with the building, and this ritual developed into - and became popular as - mochimaki.

sen.j: 神社での祭事においても餅まきは行なわれるようになった。
sen.e: Mochimaki became held also in the shrines' festivals.
Mochimaki came to be held also in the shrines' festivals.

sen.j: 典型的な餅まきは、上棟式を終えた後、建設中の住宅の屋根などから餅をまく形式である。
sen.e: A typical mochimaki is that rice cakes are scattered after jotoshiki from the roof (or other places) of a house under construction.

sen.j: 餅は、紙や食品用ラップフィルムでくるまれることが多い。
sen.e: A rice cake is mostly folded in a paper or a plastic wrap.

sen.j: また、紅白の餅が使用されるのが一般的である。
sen.e: Generally, red & white rice cakes are scattered.
Generally, red & white rice cakes are scattered.

sen.j: 地域によっては、餅以外にも「赤い紐を通した五円硬貨・五十円硬貨」といった小銭をまくなどの独自性もある。
sen.e: Some local communities have a peculiar style of scattering not only the rice cakes but also five-yen coins (or fifty-yen coins) in a red string.

sen.j: 1980年代以降、建て売り住宅の一般化、近所づきあいの希薄化などのため上棟式自体が減少したが、餅まき自体は神社や地域の祭り（ごく一部の大学祭でも見られる）などの際に、祝い事として広く行われている。
sen.e: From 1980s, jotoshiki itself has become rarer from various reasons, such as the increase of ready-built houses & the decrease of people's mixing with neighbors, but mochimaki is still held as a happy event in shrines' festivals, local communities' festivals, and some universities' festivals.

sen.j: 1956年1月1日、新潟県弥彦神社に餅まきに集まった参拝者が将棋倒しとなり、124人が死亡した。
sen.e: On January 1, 1956, visitors to Yahiko-jinja Shrine, who gathered for mochimaki, fell over like dominoes, and 124 of them died.
